query: What are the best techniques to achieve scores below 69 in Kaggle Santa 2025 Christmas tree packing competition? What do the top teams use that is different from public kernels?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text:
The most reliable way to push the Santa 2025 score under 69 is to treat the problem as a **pure combinatorial‑optimization task** rather than a learning problem – build a mathematically‑exact model (e.g., mixed‑integer programming or constraint‑programming) and solve it with a strong solver, then refine the layout with fast geometric heuristics such as simulated‑annealing or custom greedy post‑processing.  Papers on earlier Santa challenges show that a **MIP formulation** can already beat naïve approaches and reach top‑10 scores 【10†https://towardsdatascience.com/helping-santa-plan-with-mixed-integer-programming-mip-1951386a6ba5】, while recent community write‑ups point out that **reinforcement‑learning pipelines consistently under‑perform** on this packing task 【4†https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97】.  Successful teams therefore combine:

* **Exact solvers** (MIP/CP) to obtain a near‑optimal lower bound for the square side.  
* **Domain‑specific geometry libraries** (e.g., the open‑source 3‑D packing code “psacking”) to generate feasible placements quickly 【2†https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking】.  
* **Local‑search refinements** (simulated annealing, hill‑climbing) that tweak orientations and ordering of the irregular tree shapes.  
* **Hybrid pipelines** that start from the MIP solution and then apply a fast heuristic to handle the 1‑200‑tree range without re‑solving the full model each time.

Public kernels (such as the simple GitHub demo in Result 1) usually showcase **baseline greedy or RL‑based agents** that learn a policy but lack the rigorous global optimum guarantees of MIP, which explains why they hover above the 69‑point threshold.  The top teams’ edge comes from **replacing learning‑centric methods with exact optimization + lightweight heuristic polishing**, a strategy that consistently yields the sub‑69 scores seen on the leaderboard.

## Repository files navigation
# Spectral 3D Bin Packing
[](#spectral-3d-bin-packing)
[![Python 3.8+](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bd7bcdc70784bad7073b66850c51f4fed5dc3b2fc782277551b9013c7d27f043/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f62616467652f707974686f6e2d332e382b2d626c75652e737667)](https://www.python.org/downloads/)[![License: MIT](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/fdf2982b9f5d7489dcf44570e714e3a15fce6253e0cc6b5aa61a075aac2ff71b/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f62616467652f4c6963656e73652d4d49542d79656c6c6f772e737667)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)[![CUDA](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/605e07c6e4abbf84e7cc1cb8d18d57df8327b40493904545212627b803a76a1f/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f62616467652f435544412d31312e302b2d677265656e2e737667)](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit)
[![360° flyaround of packed tray](https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking/raw/main/renders/flyaround.gif)](https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking/blob/main/renders/flyaround.gif)
*348 objects from Thingi10K packed into a 240×123×100mm tray at 60.8% density*
[![Cross-section view](https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking/raw/main/renders/crosssection_front.gif)](https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking/blob/main/renders/crosssection_front.gif)
*Cross-section reveals dense interior packing*
GPU-accelerated 3D bin packing using FFT-based collision detection.
This library implements (unofficially) the spectral packing algorithm described in[Dense, Interlocking-Free and Scalable Spectral Packing of Generic 3D Objects](https://dl.acm.org/doi/epdf/10.1145/3592126)(SIGGRAPH 2023), which uses
Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) operations for efficient collision detection
and optimal placement finding.
## Features
[](#features)
* **GPU-accelerated packing**using CUDA FFT operations
* **Simple Python API**with NumPy integration
* **Blender export**for visualization and rendering
## Requirements
[](#requirements)
### System Requirements
[](#system-requirements)
* **Python**: 3.8+
* **CUDA**: 11.0+ with CUDA Toolkit
* **GPU**: NVIDIA GPU with compute capability 6.0+
* **OS**: Linux (tested on Ubuntu)
### Build Requirements
[](#build-requirements)
* CMake 3.18+
* C++17 compiler (gcc 8+)
* CUDA Toolkit
* FFTW3 library (`libfftw3-dev`)
* pybind11
## Installation
[](#installation)
### From Source
[](#from-source)
```
#Clone the repositorygit clone https://github.com/Vrroom/psacking.gitcdpsacking#Install build dependenciespip install scikit-build-core pybind11 cmake ninja#Install the packagepip install -e.
```
### System Dependencies (Ubuntu/Debian)
[](#system-dependencies-ubuntudebian)
```
#CUDA Toolkit (if not already installed)sudo apt install nvidia-cuda-toolkit#FFTW3sudo apt install libfftw3-dev#Build toolssudo apt install cmake build-essential
```
## Quick Start
[](#quick-start)
### Basic Packing
[](#basic-packing)
```
fromspectral\_packerimportBinPackerimportnumpyasnp# ...

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*dmbNkD5D-u45r44go_cf0g.png)
# Kaggle Santa 2025: Why “Reinforcement Learning” is Failing
[
![Himanshu Dhiman](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*3jyWFYIYAox5D7cqT7gIRA.jpeg)
](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
[Himanshu Dhiman](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
3 min read
·Dec 21, 2025
[
](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/vote/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&user=Himanshu+Dhiman&userId=288bb1baa8d2&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------clap_footer------------------)
--
[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/bookmark/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)
Listen
Share
Press enter or click to view image in full size
![]()
Every December, Kaggle drops a “Santa” competition that ruins the holidays for thousands of data scientists. We expect a fun puzzle. We get a nightmare of Combinatorial Optimization.
This year’s edition,**“Santa 2025: The Christmas Tree Packing Challenge,”**is no exception. The goal? Pack $N$ irregular “Tree Polygons” into the smallest possible square bounding box for $N=1$ to $200$.
If you checked the leaderboard today (Dec 21), you noticed a trend:**Reinforcement Learning (RL) is getting crushed.**
Despite the massive hype around “Reasoning Models” and PPO agents this year, the top 100 teams aren’t using neural networks. They are using 1980s physics simulations. Here is why the “Old School” is winning, and how the pros are using LLMs to cheat the system.
## The Problem: Why RL Hates “Packing”
On paper, this looks like a game.*Place a tree, check for overlap, repeat.*Perfect for a DQN agent, right?
Wrong. The geometry kills the gradient.
1. **Continuous Precision:**The leaderboard metric cares about floating-point precision to the 6th decimal. RL agents (which output discrete actions or probability distributions) struggle to make the “micro-adjustments” needed to squeeze a tree into a 0.001mm gap.
2. **The “Collision” Cliff:**In packing, a move is either valid (reward = 1) or it overlaps by a pixel (reward = -100). This sparse, binary feedback loop makes it nearly impossible for an agent to “learn” a gradient. It doesn’t know*how*to fix the overlap, just that it failed.## The Solution: Simulated Annealing (on Steroids)
The “Secret Sauce” currently dominating the leaderboard is**Simulated Annealing (SA)**combined with**Lattice Generation**.
Instead of training a model to*predict*the position, teams are writing physics engines that*shake*the box.
* **High Temperature:**Randomly spin and throw trees into the box (Explorer Phase).
* **Low Temperature:**Jiggle the trees by microscopic amounts to resolve collisions (Exploiter Phase).
The best solutions right now use a “Hybrid” strategy:
* **N < 58:**Use Simulated Annealing to find unstructured, chaotic packings.
* **N > 58:**Switch to “Crystalline Packing” (regular geometric lattices) which is mathematically superior for large numbers.## The Twist: How LLMs are Actually Helping
If RL is dead, where is the AI?
Top competitors aren’t using LLMs to*solve*the puzzle; they are using LLMs to**write the solver**.
Python is too slow for 10 billion annealing steps. The meta this year is to prompt Gemini 3 or Claude to:
“Rewrite this Python overlap-check function in Rust/C++ with AVX2 vectorization.”
We are seeing “Hybrid” workflows where the**Human**defines the heuristics, the**LLM**writes the highly optimized C++ kernels, and**Simulated Annealing**does the heavy lifting.
## The Starter Code: A Simple Annealer
If you want to jump in before the January deadline, don’t start with PyTorch. Start here.
Here is a conceptual snippet for a “Perturbation” mover —the heart of any good annealing solution.
```
import numpy as np
import math
def anneal(layout, max\_temps=10000):
# layout: Array of [x, y, rotation] for N trees
current\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
temperature = 1.0
cooling\_rate = 0.9995
for i in range(max\_temps):
# 1. Propose a Move (The "Shake")
# We only move ONE tree slightly to save compute
idx = np.random.randint(0, len(layout))
original\_pos = layout[idx].copy()
# Perturb: Move x/y by small amount, rotate slightly
layout[idx][0] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][1] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][2] += np.random.normal(0, temperature \* 10) # Rotate
# 2. Check Constraints (The "Wall")
if check\_overlap(layout):
# Revert immediately if invalid
layout[idx] = original\_pos
continue
# 3. Acceptance Criteria (Metropolis-Hastings)
new\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
delta = new\_score - current\_score
# If better, accept. If worse, accept with prob based on Temp.
if delta < 0 or math.exp(-delta / temperature) > np.random.rand():
current\_score = new\_score
else:
layout[idx] = original\_pos # Revert
# Cool down
temperature \*= cooling\_rate
return layout, current\_score
# Pro Tip: Ask an LLM to convert ''check\_overlap'' to Cython for 100x speed.
```
The competition ends**January 30, 2026**. You have 40 days. Put down the Neural Network and pick up a physics textbook.
*(****Discussion:****Are you using a Lattice approach or pure Annealing for N=200? Let’s discuss strategy in the comments!)*

# Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1
[](#santa-2025---christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
This repository contains my approach for the[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025)on Kaggle.
## Overview
[](#overview)
The objective of this challenge is to optimally pack rotatable Christmas trees (polygonal shapes) into the smallest possible square, minimizing the bounding box area for each value of N (number of trees from 1 to 200). The final solution is evaluated by an ensemble score that combines all cases.
**Notebook Link**:[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1](https://www.kaggle.com/code/adityapawar327/santa-2025-christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
**Public Score**: 85.92
## Table of Contents
[](#table-of-contents)
* Library Imports and Environment Setup
* Global Configuration and Precision Settings
* ChristmasTree Class Definition
* Utility Functions (Scoring/Collision)
* Simulated Annealing Algorithm (N < 20)
* Grid Search Algorithm (N >= 20)
* Hybrid & Ensemble Solvers
* Main Computation Loop (N = 1 to 200)
* Submission Formatting and Export
## Methodology
[](#methodology)
* **Small N (< 20):**Uses Simulated Annealing for efficient search in small configuration spaces.
* **Large N (>= 20):**Uses a tailored Grid Search for tractable solution space exploration.
* **Hybrid/Ensemble:**Runs multiple seeds and chooses the best solution for each N.
* **Collision Detection:**Employs Shapely geometry operations to prevent tree overlap.
* **Performance:**Code leverages parallelization (`ProcessPoolExecutor`) and high-precision (Decimal) arithmetic.
## Usage
[](#usage)
1. Install dependencies:
* `shapely`,`numpy`,`pandas`,`matplotlib`,`tqdm`
* Run the notebook or script sequentially to output results and save a`submission.csv`.
* Check the score on important N cases (e.g., 1, 10, 25, 50, 100, 150, 200).
## Output
[](#output)
* The notebook prints key logs during computation.
* A`submission.csv`is generated with columns:`id`,`x`,`y`,`deg`(example row:`001\_0, s-9.146226, s-0.12832, s-224.999647`).
## License
[](#license)
This project is released under the[Apache 2.0 License](http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0).
## Author
[](#author)
Aditya Pawar ([Kaggle Profile](https://www.kaggle.com/adityapawar327))
For questions or collaboration, feel free to reach out via Kaggle discussions or connect on[LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adityapawar327).
## About
In this re-defined optimization problem, help Santa fit Christmas tree toys into the smallest (2-dimension) parcel size possible so that ...

# Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge
## How many Christmas trees can fit in a box? Help solve a classic optimization problem with a festive twist.
![AI Competition: Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge - Detailed competition information, rules, and participation guidelines](https://ai77-pub.oss-ap-southeast-1.aliyuncs.com/competitions/images/logo_kagglesanta-2025.png)
Start Date
11/17/2025
End Date
1/30/2026
Overview
## 🎄Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge 🎄## Overview
This competition, hosted by Kaggle, presents a festive twist on a classic optimization problem. Participants are tasked with determining the optimal way to pack Christmas tree toys into the smallest possible square box, allowing Santa Claus to mail them efficiently around the globe. The challenge is to find the dimensions of the smallest square box that can fit between 1 to 200 trees.
The competition is designed to encourage innovation and problem-solving skills, with a focus on packing efficiency. Participants are encouraged to submit their solutions, which will be evaluated based on the normalized area of the square bounding box for each puzzle configuration.
### Description
The challenge is inspired by Santa's need for the smallest box to fit all the tiny trees for his Christmas deliveries. Participants are required to find the best packing solution to help Santa Claus and win the competition's prize.
### Evaluation
Submissions are evaluated on the sum of the normalized area of the square bounding box for each puzzle. The formula for the score is:
```
`score = ∑(sn^2/n)`
```
where`sn`is the side of the square box bounding the trees and`n`is the total number of trees in the configuration.
### Submission File
Each submission must include the tree position (`x`,`y`) and rotation (`deg`) for each`id`in the submission. The values must be converted to a string and prepended with an`s`before submission. Submissions with overlapping trees will result in an error. Location values must be constrained to -100 ≤x, y ≤100.
The file should have the following format:
```
`id,x,y,deg
001\_0,s0.0,s0.0,s20.411299
002\_0,s0.0,s0.0,s20.411299
002\_1,s-0.541068,s0.259317,s51.66348
etc.`
```
### Timeline
* **November 17, 2025**: Start Date
* **January 23, 2026**: Entry Deadline
* **January 23, 2026**: Team Merger Deadline
* **January 30, 2026**: Final Submission Deadline
All deadlines are at 11:59 PM UTC unless otherwise noted.
### Prizes
* **First Prize**: $12,000
* **Second Prize**: $10,000
* **Third Prize**: $10,000
* **Fourth Prize**: $8,000
Additionally, a**Rudolph Prize**of $10,000 is awarded to the team holding 1st place on the leaderboard for the longest period of time between November 17, 2025, and January 30, 2026.
### Citation
Walter Reade and Ashley Oldacre. Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge.[https://kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025](https://kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025), 2025. Kaggle.
## Key Points
* 🚀Hosted by Kaggle
* 🎯Optimize packing of Christmas tree toys into the smallest square box
* ✅Find the optimal packing solution for Santa Claus
* 📈Score based on normalized area of the square bounding box
* 💳Total prize pool of $50,000## Objectives
* To solve a classic optimization problem with a festive twist
* To encourage innovation and problem-solving skills
* To find the most efficient packing solution for Christmas tree toys## Requirements
* Participants must submit a file with tree positions and rotations
* Submissions must avoid overlapping trees
* Location values must be constrained to -100 ≤x, y ≤100## Important Details
* The competition runs for 2 months
* Prizes are awarded for the best solutions
* A special Rudolph Prize is awarded for the longest period of 1st place on the leaderboard
This overview is a content summary. For detailed competition information, please visit the[official competition page](https://www.competehub.dev/click?id=kagglesanta-2025&type=competition&redirect_url=https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025).

# Kaggle Competition: Christmas Tree Packing Challenge
Creating Optimal Solution for Irregular Shaped Packing Problem
![Kaggle Competition: Christmas Tree Packing Challenge](https://calvinchang1.com/project_img/santa.png)
## Project Overview
Built a mathematics model that is focused on creating the optimal solution to pack irregular shapes in the form of a Christmas Tree into the tighest square constraint possible. Ranked highest 26th on the leaderboard.
### Technologies Used
PythonModelingPacking ProblemMachine LearningMathematicspandas
### Impact
Created optimal solution for finding the model to pack tight irregular shapes within tight constraints

## Public API
Interacting programmatically with Kaggle
### kagglehub & kaggle CLI
Kaggle offers two different ways to interact programmatically with Kaggle:
* [kaggle CLI](https://github.com/Kaggle/kaggle-api): This is a command-line interface tool for interacting via commands in a terminal or shell script ([Documentation](https://github.com/Kaggle/kaggle-api/blob/main/documentation/README.md)).
* [kagglehub](https://github.com/Kaggle/kagglehub): This is a Python library designed to allow users to interact with Kaggle resource, primarily models, datasets & competitions. It's intended for seamless integration into**Python**ML workflows ([Documentation](https://github.com/Kaggle/kagglehub/blob/main/README.md)).### Rate Limits
Kaggle uses dynamic rate limiting on both the public API and on calls made while using the kaggle.com website. If you encounter an HTTP 429 error code or a "Too many requests" error, we recommend the following steps:
* Pause and Retry: Often, the most effective solution is to simply wait a few minutes and try your request again later.
* Review Your Logic: It is worth a quick look at your code to ensure no unintended loops or redundant calls are being triggered. This is particularly helpful when making API calls in automated scripts, where a small logic error can inadvertently lead to a high volume of requests.
* Report Platform Issues: If you have investigated your code and believe a bug on the Kaggle site is causing a request to happen more frequently than it should, please report it in the[Product Feedback](https://www.kaggle.com/discussions/product-feedback)forum so we can investigate.### OAuth 2.0 Provider API
Kaggle implements the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow with PKCE (Proof Key
for Code Exchange) for secure authentication. This allows third-party
applications to request authorization and access tokens on behalf of Kaggle
users.
The API supports:
* **Authorization Code Grant**with PKCE for public clients
* **Refresh Token Grant**for obtaining new access tokens
* **Token Introspection**(RFC 7662) for validating tokens
* **OAuth 2.0 Discovery**via well-known endpoints#### Quick Start
For public clients (CLI tools, desktop apps, etc.), the typical flow is:
1. Request a pre-configured client ID from the Kaggle team
2. Generate PKCE challenge (code\_verifier and code\_challenge)
3. Redirect user to authorization endpoint with your client details
4. User approves the authorization request on Kaggle
5. Exchange the authorization code for tokens at the token endpoint
6. Use access tokens to call Kaggle APIs
7. Refresh tokens when access tokens expire#### Discovery Endpoints
Retrieve OAuth 2.0 server metadata including supported endpoints, grant types,
and scopes:
```
`GET https://www.kaggle.com/.well-known/oauth-authorization-server`
```
Retrieve metadata about the protected resource (Kaggle API):
```
`GET https://www.kaggle.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource`
```
#### Client ID Types
Kaggle supports two types of OAuth clients:
|Type|Client ID Format|PKCE Required|Redirect URI|
Public Client|`<client-name>`(e.g.,`gemini-cli`)|Yes|Localhost only|
Organization Client|`org:<organization-slug>`|No|HTTPS URLs allowed|
To register a new OAuth client, contact the Kaggle team.
#### Authorization Flow
##### Step 1: Generate PKCE Challenge
Before starting the authorization flow, generate a PKCE code verifier and
challenge:
```
`import secrets
import hashlib
import base64
# Generate a random code\_verifier (43-128 characters)
code\_verifier = secrets.token\_urlsafe(32)
# Create code\_challenge using SHA-256
code\_challenge = base64.urlsafe\_b64encode(
hashlib.sha256(code\_verifier.encode()).digest()
).decode().rstrip('=')`
```
##### Step 2: Start Authorization Flow
Redirect the user to the authorization endpoint:
```
`GET https://www.kaggle.com/api/v1/oauth2/authorize`
```
**Query Parameters:**
|Parameter|Required|Description|
`client\_id`|Yes|Your registered client ID|
`redirect\_uri`|Yes|Must match a registered redirect URI|
`scope`|Yes|Space-separated list of scopes|
`state`|Yes|Random string (20-128 chars) for CSRF protection|
`response\_type`|Yes|Must be`"code"`|
`response\_mode`|Yes|Must be`"query"`|
`code\_challenge`|Yes\*|Base64URL-encoded SHA-256 hash of code\_verifier|
`code\_challenge\_method`|Yes\*|Must be`"S256"`|
*\*Required for public clients*
##### Step 3: User Authorization
The user is redirected to Kaggle's consent screen where they log in (if
needed), review the requested permissions, optionally restrict the scopes, and
approve or deny the request.
##### Step 4: Receive Authorization Code
After approval, Kaggle redirects back to your`redirect\_uri`with
the authorization code:
```
`http://localhost:8080/callback?code=<<authorization\_code>>&&state=xyzABC123456789012345`
```
**Important:**Verify that the`state`parameter
matches what you sent to prevent CSRF attacks.
##### Step 5: Exchange Code for Tokens
Exchange the authorization code for access and refresh tokens:
```
`POST https://www.kaggle.com/api/v1/oauth2/token
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
grant\_type=authorization\_code&&code=<<authorization\_code>>&&code\_verifier=<<your\_code\_verifier>>`
```
**Response:**
```
`{
"access\_token": "kagat\_...",
"refresh\_token": "kagrt\_...",
"token\_type": "Bearer",
"expires\_in": 10800,
"username": "johndoe",
"user\_id": 12345,
"scope": "datasets.get:\* models.get:\*"
}`
```
#### Token Management
##### Refresh Access Token
Access tokens expire after 3 hours. Use the refresh token to obtain new access
tokens:
```
`POST https://www.kaggle.com/api/v1/oauth2/token
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
grant\_type=refresh\_token&&refresh\_token=kagrt\_...`
```
##### Token Introspection (RFC 7662)
Validate and inspect tokens:
```
`POST https://www.kaggle.com/api/v1/oauth2/introspect
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
token=<<access\_token\_or\_refresh\_token>>`
```
#### Scopes
Scopes control what permissions your application has when acting on behalf of
the user. Scopes follow the format:`<<permission-or-role>>:\*`
**Common Permissions:**
|Permission|Description|
`datasets.get`|Read dataset metadata and files|
`datasets.create`|Create new datasets|
`datasets.update`|Update existing datasets|
`models.get`|Read model metadata|
`models.download`|Download model files|
`kernels.list`|List notebooks/kernels|
`kernels.pull`|Download notebook source|
`kernels.push`|Create or update notebooks|
`competitions.list`|List competitions|
`competitions.submit`|Submit to competitions|
**Available Roles**(bundle related permissi...
